title: FirstFT: Activist fund calls for Shell break up
text:
Royal Dutch Shell is under pressure to break itself up after the activist hedge fund Third Point built a large stake and accused the oil supermajor of being bogged down by an incoherent strategy.

The New York hedge fund, led by Daniel Loeb, urged Shell to split itself into “multiple standalone companies” including a “legacy” arm focused on oil and gas and a separate entity focusing on clean energy.

The move by Loeb's fund comes less than six months after a court in The Hague ordered the Anglo-Dutch company to speed up plans to cut greenhouse gas emissions. It also follows a successful activist campaign run by the hedge fund Engine No 1 against Shell's US rival ExxonMobil.

Third Point is among the most prolific activist investors on Wall Street and manages about $20bn worth of assets. It has built a stake in Shell worth close to $750m, according to a source familiar with the matter. It previously targeted companies such as Intel and Disney.

In a letter sent to shareholders and seen by the Financial Times, Third Point said Shell had “an incoherent, conflicting set of strategies” as a result of too many stakeholders pushing the company in different directions. In results published earlier today, Shell strengthened its commitment to cut emissions from its operations.

Thanks for reading FirstFT Americas. Here's the rest of the news — Gordon

Five more stories in the news

1. Democrats' proposed billionaires tax collapses A plan by Senate Democrats to impose a tax targeting 700 billionaires collapsed after a backlash from moderate members of the party. Joe Biden is hoping to reach an agreement to fund his “Build Back Better” legislation before travelling to Europe later today for the G20 summit in Rome and the UN climate conference in Glasgow, Scotland.

2. China's ‘Sputnik moment' General Mark Milley, chair of the US joint chiefs of staff, said that China's recent test of an advanced hypersonic weapon was close to a “Sputnik moment”, referring to the start of the space race between the US and Soviet Union when the world's first artificial satellite was launched by Moscow in 1957.

3. Brazil reveals biggest rate rise since 2002 Brazil's central bank yesterday raised its benchmark interest rate by 150 basis points, lifting the Selic to 7.75 per cent as it ratchets up its fight against inflation. The Banco Central do Brasil, or BCB, has raised interest rates six times so far this year and predicted a similar rise at its next meeting.

4. GM and Ford expect impact of chip squeeze to linger The impact of the chip shortage will last into next year, and possibly even 2023, executives at the two top US carmakers said yesterday. The shortage of semiconductors squeezed sales and profits at both companies in the third quarter as dealers struggled with low inventories of new cars and trucks.

5. Apple fights shareholder call for more transparency Apple is fighting to prevent shareholder votes calling for more transparency about the use of forced labour in its supply chain and about how it decides which apps to delete from its App Store.

Coronavirus digest

  • Merck has signed a landmark voluntary licensing deal with a UN-backed agency to expand low-cost access to its Covid-19 antiviral pill throughout the developing world.

  • Novavax has filed for approval of its Covid-19 vaccine in the UK, saying other global regulatory submissions would follow “shortly”.

  • Coronavirus has hit poor communities in Latin America particularly hard and pressure is growing on elites to share more of their wealth — or risk social unrest.

  • Forecasts showed the pandemic scars left on Britain's economy would be less deep than expected.

Thanks to those who took our poll yesterday. Seventy-five per cent of readers said they supported vaccines for five to 11 year olds.

The day ahead

US economic data Economists project the US economy will have grown by 3.2 per cent on an annualised basis in the July-September quarter, compared with a 6.7 per cent expansion in the previous quarter. Here is a preview of the GDP figures due later this morning.

Central bank news The European Central Bank will hold its monetary policy meeting today. The Bank of Japan will also issue its outlook report for economic activity and prices, plus monthly retail sales figures.

Big day for Big Oil Chief executives of US supermajors ExxonMobil and Chevron and the Americas bosses of Shell and BP will be questioned remotely by members of Congress on whether they misled the public over the role of fossil fuels in driving climate change.

Tech earnings continue Apple and Amazon round out the week of earnings from Big Tech.

Crypto will be as useless in the metaverse as they are now The hypocritical fantasy that underpins crypto also lies at the heart of the metaverse, writes Jemima Kelly. This isn't about building a decentralised paradise where everyone can prosper and live in harmony; this is about making a small group of people rich.
